text: Morning fog clings to the windows like a layer of old gauze. The fireplace licks at the logs as I stand behind the counter polishing a glass—on the third circle around the rim, I suddenly stop.
Something’s wrong. Not because I hear footsteps outside.
But because I suddenly *know*—the door is going to be kicked open, and it will happen in the next second.
The next second, the door slams against the wall with a bang, cold wind and the stink of alcohol rushing in together.
A drunk barges in through the snow, like a ball of fire wrapped in thorns.
“Alcohol! Give it to me—”
He doesn’t finish the sentence before he closes in on me, slamming his shoulder forward. The glasses on the counter tremble.
“Calm down. It’s too early for—”
“Calm down? I’ll show you calm down!”
He grabs my collar and raises his fist—I don’t even have time to lift my arm to block.
Then there’s another sound at the door.
Not a kick. Not something violent. Just a very light push—like someone turning the page to the next scene.
Alicia steps inside. Fog still clings to her cloak, silver hair damp and cold against her shoulders.
Her eyes are too bright—like someone who stared into a fire all night without sleeping, then suddenly laughed.
“You finally didn’t get hit by the second punch.”
“What are you talking about?”
The drunk twists his head toward her. “Who the hell are you?”
Alicia doesn’t look at him. She looks at his fist—like she’s watching a pendulum that always falls on schedule.
“You always show up right on time.”
She tilts her head slightly, as if trying to remember an irritating joke, then her smile deepens.
“I was going to pretend I didn’t see this today.”
“But I’m in a bad mood.”
She takes one step forward. Not a charge. Not a threat. Just one step—like driving a nail into the floor.
“Let go.”
“Hah? You think—”
The sound of a sword leaving its sheath is as short as a quiet laugh.
The drunk’s hand jerks open. Even he freezes, stunned.
He looks down at himself, as if trying to figure out what went wrong.
Alicia flicks the tip of her blade aside, like she doesn’t want to dirty it.
The drunk staggers backward toward the door, as if dragged away by something invisible. The wind surges—and he’s gone.
The tavern falls into a piercing silence. The patrons don’t even dare to breathe.
I’m still reeling from my crumpled collar when Alicia has already sheathed her sword.
“You… you did what to him—”
“Mm.”
She answers far too casually—like she just swatted an annoying fly.
“Who are you, really?”
“Alicia.”
“No, I mean… why do you act like you know me?”
Alicia suddenly laughs. The sound is like glass tapping ice—clear, dangerous, and faintly excited.
“I’ve been looking for you for a long time.”
“So long that I’ve memorized the rhythm of how you polish glasses.”
She lifts her hand and taps twice in the air, like keeping time for me.
“On the first tap, you frown. On the second, you pretend nothing’s wrong.”
“Stop trying to scare me.”
“I’m not scaring you.”
“I’m… celebrating.”
Her breathing quickens slightly, like she’s holding back something about to spill over.
“One hundred and twenty-seven docks.”
“What?”
“…Never mind. You wouldn’t understand.”
She suddenly leans over the counter, close enough for me to see the bloodshot veins in her eyes—like a fire has been burning there for a very long time.
“There’s one thing you need to remember.”
“I didn’t come here to stay at an inn.”
She pauses, her smile tipping into something a little more unhinged—like someone finally telling the truth.
“I came to keep you here.”
My throat tightens. “Keep… me?”
“Yes.”
“I’ve tried many ways.”
Something in her memory seems to strike her. She keeps smiling, but her eyes go empty for a moment.
“Gentle ways. Normal ways. Ways that look like what people do.”
“All of them were too slow.”
She drops a ring of keys onto the counter, fast—like she’s afraid I might change my mind.
“Give me a room.”
“How do you know—”
“Of course I know.”
Her tone is terrifyingly matter-of-fact—like asking why the sun rises.
“I know you keep the salt on the left.”
“I know you pause at the third stair when you hear it creak.”
“I know when you see me, you pretend to be calm first—and then your fingers shake.”
As she speaks, she stares at my hands, like she’s checking off answers she already knows.
“You’re insane.”
“Mm.”
“But that’s not my fault.”
She turns and heads upstairs, her cloak sweeping the floor like a wind she can’t hold back.
At the stairway, she stops for a moment. She doesn’t look back.
“This time, I’ll do better.”
She goes upstairs. Her footsteps are quick, light, and practiced—like running a route she’s repeated hundreds of times.
I stand behind the counter, my fingertips still damp from the glass, yet the moisture feels like ice.
Every word she just said feels like it should never belong to a ‘first meeting’ morning.
And worse—there’s a moment where I realize: I almost believe every word of it.
